Runaway from the Subscriber, some time since,
lad named JAMES R. Towns, an apprentice to the
Shoe Making business. He is about go years old,
well grown for his age. Had on and took with him
blue cloth coat and pantalets, and blue surtout, to-
rether with sundry other clothing. The above re-
ward will be paid to any person who will appre-
hend said boy, together with reasonable charges if
brought home. All persons are forbid harbourns
him at their peril. JAMES SIMPSON.


LV;ln;upton Del Oct 26. 1927. 55--4t
Ten Dollars Reward.

The meeting of citizens on Wednesday evening
at the Capitol, to express their disapprobaton Of
Gen. Jackson's election, was great and overwhel-
the extremity--the benches and the intervals be-
tween them--the windows, the area in the centre of
the room, the lobby and gallery, filled to sufo-
cation.-The crowd was so great that the business
of the evening conducted with great difficulty,
and those who came prepared to address the assem-
blage were compelled to reinquish that purpose.
Richmond from her foundation, has seen no meeting
so powerful in numbers, so venerable from the age,
responsibility and talent of those assembled. We
knew it would be large, but it very far exceeded our
most sanguine expectations-we knew it would be
respectable, but that term is deficient in significance
to express its character.

From the Richmond Whig, Oct. s7.
GREAT MEETING AT THE CAPITOL.

an opposition meeting in one of the wards in n.
York, settles the question at once, by Resolving
That they view with Indignation the bare faced bar
gaining between John Quincy Adams and Henry
Clay!


II might save time to have form of Resolve for
all the opposition meetings, running thus: Resolved
That every imputation against the Administration
is true-that every imputation against Gen. Jackson
is false and he that don't admit this, "has more
brains than an oyster'


There would, of course, be an end of debate, and
thousands of words columns and pages, be saved.
The only regret would be that. .sucha modest Resolve
had not been passed sooner!


Boston Palladium.

Captain Sheffield, who arrived at New York on
Wednesday morning, in eighteen days from Car
thagena, states that Bolivar made his entry into
Bogota on the 1th of September, and was received
with great applause He took the oath of office and
the Presidents chair on the same day.


The Legislature of New Jersey commenced its an
nual session at Trenton on the s9d inst The Pres
ident of the Council or Senate the Speaker of the
House of Representatives, and all the Clerks and
Door-keepers were chosen from amongst the friends
of the Administrations In the Senate, the parties
stand-For the Administration 10-or Jackson q;
and in the House of Representatives-For the Ad-
minisration 29--for Sackson Is. In joint meet


ing there are, of course. two to in favor OF the
Administration. The Editor of the New Bruns-
wick FREEDMAN says, that the majority for Mr..
Adams, in 1928, will exceed Ten thousand.
A duel took place at Rio DE JANE1Ro, on the goth
of August last between Midshipmen BIspHAM, and
Surgeon BRANDNER, of the United States sloop OF
War Peacock-the latter was 50 badly wounded
that he died on the following day-two shots were
also exchanged by the seconds, neither OF whom
were wounded.

Boston Palladium.


From the Boston Courier.


VERMONT At the late election in this State
His Excellency Ezra Butler was reelected Cover
nor. Mr.. Swan who has been treasurer of the State
for several years was reelected, having all but eigh
teen of the votes ih the State in his favour. The
following is an extract from the inaugural Speech Of
Governor Butler.


The people of this state can never remain indf-
erent observers Of the proceedings OF Congress, or
the course pursued by the Executive of the general
government. And we have too much confidence
in the rectitude of motives, and correctness OF
our views, to conceal them. So far as the pub
lie good may require, they should be made known.
Let every state in the union do the and it may
be OF some service to that government on which we
all depend for national security, and the protection
of our rights. The dereliction of duty in the last
Congress, so we'll calculated to impair the confidence
of the public in the national legislature, is matter
of serious regret, For that body to refuse protec.
ton to the industry of majority of the people, when
the necessity had become too obvious to be mistaken
is just cause of complaint; for it is wounding te
the laudabe pride Of our country.


| Had no other important interest been neglected
the wound would have been less painful, and might
have been born in silence. However, for the pre-
sent, we can but cherish the hope. that by the mex
Congress all just cause of dissatisfaction will be re
moved, and the confidence of the people again re
stored to Legislature on whose wisdom and integ
rty, the United States, are in so high degree, de
pendent for her prosperity.


I The American system must, and will be sup
ported; Or the retrograde march Of country viii
i soon commence.


GoLatest from Europe--Papers, by the Sila
Richards, to the s4th September, have been re
ceived at New York. The chief matter of interes
is the apparent purpose of the Turks to resist tn
mediation of the European powers. The oficia
note of the Ministers of France, England and Russi
will be published in our next. Having receives
no answer, they are said to have demanded thei
passports.


Bank Robbery.-From the following advertisement
in Petersburg paper, 1t appears that the Teller
one of the Banks has absconded with large sum
money. We have not been able to gather any fu
ther particulars Mr.. Snelson is represented a
having borne fair character. His conduct is sal
to have been discreet and his habits regular an
that his style of living bordered upon parsimony
ther than extravaganza. The public are at loss
conjectures.what circumstances could have induced
man thus Situated, and grey with years, to blast hi
reputation, by such an act. 1t is said, with whs
truth we know not, that he sent $4,000 to his wife
which she returned to the Bank with promptitud
that reflects the highest credit upon her sense of hor
orr Richmond Enquirer.
:. Fsue hundred dollars re,oard-Nathaniel Snelsor
the Teller of the Office of Discount and Deposite
the Bank of Virginia, in Petersburg, has stole
from the said office about forty thousand dollars, chic
ly in notes of one hundred dollars each, the prope
ty of the President, Directors and Company, Of tn
Bank of Virginia; and he absconded early on Sur
day morning. having as is believed, very large po
tion of that with him. 1t is understood that h
got into one of the Steamboats, below City Point
the same morning.


{ am authorized by the Board of Directors Of tt
said office, to offer the above reward and all reasons
BILE expenses, for his apprehension and safe deliver
to the Jailor of this town.


Sneson is about fifty years of age, about feet
inches highs his hair very grey; his face red an
full, with clear blue eyes. He hesitates, and gene
ally appears embarrassed when speaking.
u G. w. STAINBACK, Cashier.

pei te present inCuWDeHlS LFOl OInCe, lnat lley may
fill their places"


Twenty-four passengers in the Union Steamboat
Line from Philadelphia to Baltimore, have publish
ed in the National Intelligencer, Oct 49, the /" fol-
lowing facts"


"Owing, entirely, to the careessness and intem-
perance Of two drivers, and the attempting to
pass and the other to prevent it, one of the Stages
going from Newcastle to Frenchtown. this day,
Oct 27, containing seven passengers, was over
turned, and five persons badly injured, two of them
dangerously so, viz: Rev. Bishop Kemp, of Balti-
more, and Doctor Hamilton, of Petersburgh.'


We understand that Bishop Kemp has since died
in Baltimore.


On Thursday last, the Rev. DR. u. ONDERpoNK
was consecrated Assistant Bishop of the Diocess Of
Pennsylvania. The ceremonies of Conservation took
place in Christ Church Philadelphi Sermon by
Bishop HOBART, Of New-York. j


An Administration Meeting was held at the Court
House, in Lexington, Kentucky. on the 18th inst.
for the purpose of appointing Delegates to the Con-
vention, to be held on the 18th December, to nom-
natean Electoral Ticket. The Kentucky Reporter
states that several of the most respectable Of the
Jackson party'' attended that meeting. Mr. Buc-
hanan's letter must have had its natural effect in
Kentucky, well as in other states, and the reac-
ton which has taken place on the minds of candid
and inquring men, not only has been extensive, but
will prove much more so as we hear from the most
distant parts of our country.

From the National h,teHgencer.


Extracts Of letter from Richmond dated 25th Oc-


tober.


"You will learn, with pleasure, that we held an
anti Jackson meeting in this city last evening, Judge
CABELL acting as chairman, and WM G. PENpIE-
TON, Secretary. 1t was truly the most numerous
and respectable meeting every held here, on any oc
casion whatever. The Rev. JOHN KERR, formerly
member of Congress, CHAPMAN JOHNSON, and
MIR. CALL, were appointed delegates to the Conven-
ton in January. The old Republicans Of the city
turned out in body =; and on the Corresponding
Committee you will find, among others, the names
OF Judge CARR. Mr.. STANARD, Mr. IhOs. RUTHER-
FooRD. Judge CABELI, Mr. RooTEs, Gen. HARvIE,
&c. CHAPMAN JOHNSON rode seventy miles yester-
day to reach the meeting in time and he has become
jealous and active in his exertions. You may rely
upon it that the Convention ball is moving rapidly
and it is impossible now to arrest its progress The
People are beginning TO the danger of hazarding
their liberties in the hands of General Jackson and,
with proper understanding of the relative merits
of the candidates, but little doubt is entertained.
by many cool and sagacious men, that the vote OF
| Virginia will be against the 6 Hero.' The party
here are seriously alarmed at the general movement
of the People and hence, the bold assertions OF the
Enquirer; that the objects of the convention will
fail, and their untirng efforts to defeat the measure.
The only advantage they have over us, is legsla-
tive caucus if indeed they can get up one' which
begin to doubt.''


" / forgot to tell you that our meeting consisted
of at least 600 persons The Delegates Hall was
crowded to overaowing, and many returned who
could not get in.' Sail the Judges of the court of
Appeals attended, except Judge GREEN. Conver-
sions have been made to our side in various and
different parts of the State l do not mean to
deceive you when say, that very considerable
change, in favor of the Administration, is every day
taking place."


The Heroites are shooting off their long guns and
ringing their bells for what they are pleased to call
'sa victory in Ohio" A Jackson man has been elec-
ted to Congress in the District of Ohio lately repre-
sented by Mr.. Wilson deceased, who was friendly
to the Administrations but it is well known that there
were two, if not three administration candidates to
one Heroite, and that the Heroite succeeded in
sequence of the division. There are fourteen men,
bers of the lower House of Congress and two Sen
ators from Ohio, THIRTEEN Of whom are decided
friends of the Administration. Two thirds of the
Legislature, just elected, also friendly to the Ad
ministration and in almost every instance the Jack
sonmen who did succeed were elected by diminished
maiorities. Combination may expect just such
another in victory Ohio in 1928, as they have re-
cent? gained in Delaware.

Clay continues matter Of dispute in the papers

The meetings in Virginia, friendly to the Admi-
nistraton, multiply rapidly. On the 10th one took
place, composed of people from Shepherds Town
and its vicinity. From the preamble to their reso-
lutions, we copy the following;


1t has been admitted by all parties in this state,
that Mr.. Adams, at the last presidential election,
was the second choice Of the people of Virginia.
lti also believed that he the second choice OF
majority of our Representatives in Congress and
we have perceived nothing in his election by Con-
gress, or in his Administration since his election to
impair the confidence then reposed in him by ma
iority of the people of Virginia, although his cleo
ton and administration, have been assailed with
bitterness and violence, rarely equalled, by
one of the most formidable combinations, originating
at the seat Of government, that has ever existed in
this country; combination composed mostly of dis
appointed asprants for Office, the cement Of whose
union is no political principle.


$ The charge ofintrigue, bargain and corruption,
IN the election of Mr.. Adams, which has been cir.
cuated secretly and publicly with indefatgable in
dustry-North and South, East and West. from the
tapitol-and has been bolstered up by bold infer
ehces, dark inuendoes and the voluntary exparte
statements of unsworn and interested witnesses, can
have no credcnce with the calm, rejecting, and un-
preludced people of Virginia


The charge against Mr.. CLAY, of having made
corrupt proposition to general Jackson, has been
'r'umphanty refuted by the witnesses who were ad-
tuced to convict him, but his enemies have not yet
the masnanmiy to acknowledge it, The support
so General jackson, conscious of his inleriorty
to Mr.. Adams in all the necessary qualifications for
me o!hre of President of the United States, have
been driven into the measure of impeachng the ho-
nesty OF MIR. Adams, i'll order to degrade him below
the level of their chief, whose honesty they throw
over him as panoply which is to cover all his er-
Ir'rs and deficiencies. But has it come to this9
Is General Jackson the only honest in the Uni
ted States we have seen Mr.. Adams, in the midst
OF all the storms and connections which have been
excited around him, pursuing the policy of his pre-
decessors, with camncss, firmness, berality, and
eonstancy OF assiluity. that must command the ap
probation of all the rejecting and unprejudiced peo
Re OF the United States and we conceive it to be
inc duty of the people actively to lend their aid
VIRGINIA..

We perceive, by notice in the fredericksburg
Arena, that meeting of the inhabitants of that town.
and OF Falmouth, and the adjacent country, will take
place IN Fredericksburg on the 10th of November.
LOT the purpose OF considering the expediency OF
creating company for the manufacture of woollen
and cotton cloths and linens.'' The falls of the
Rappahannock said to present great induce
ments to the erection of manufactures j; and it is
certainly very desirable to turn slave labor to
ry possible advantage.


Brazil and Buenos .Ayres-By the United States
ship Peacock, which touched at Rio Janeiro, on her
passage home from the Pacific, information was re-
ceived that new treaty was about to be offered to
the Buenos Ayreans by the Emperorof Brazil which
it was expected would be accepted, the Emperor
having abandoned the claim to the Banda Oriental,
which one of the principal features of the treaty.
Free Port in the Pacifc-By the following letter,
addressed to the Collector Of New York, it will be
seen that Free Port has been established in the
Pacific, by the Congress of Colombia.


CONSULATE OF THE UNITED STATES,


Carthagena, Oct. 1, 1927


SIR: / have the honour to hand an act OF the Con-
grass Of Colombia, declaring Buenaventura, in the
Pacific, free port, which request you will make
public. for the information of the merchants of the





obedient servant,


j. M. MACPHERSON, CoYsul.
To the Collector of the Port Of New York.


Cuba.-An official detailed report of the trade Of
the Island of Cuba for the year 1885, states that the
receipts of the Royal Treasury, in that year. are
seven millions of hard dollars This vast increase
of the public revenue says the Report, is due to the
vigilance and ability exercised in that department
tho adj ipia has enabled
government Of Cuba to meet the new and heavy ex-
penditures required in order to put the island in
spectacle state Of defence, to repair all damages to
cover all demands and there remains clear sur
plus of more than half million, at the beginning
of the present year.


| THE BIBLE OFFERED TO NIL.


Whereas it is to be feared that many families in the
County of Newcastle living without the Bible in their
houses because they deem themselves too poor to pur-
chase one, from other This is to give no.
tce all such families, that they may obtain good COM
mon Bible Testament by applying to any Minister fhe
Gospel of any Christian denomination, or to any Elder OF
Church, any Editor of Newspaper in this County.


The object of the Delaware Bible Society, and of the
other Bible Societies in this County, is to put the Bible
into every house and within the reach of every individual
To those who unable unwilling to pay any thing 1t
will be given gratuousy. From those who wiling to
pay the whole part OF the price, payment will be gladly
received and appropriated to the purchase Of others TO


When the applicant for Bible is unknown to the Min.
ster Elder or Editor he may apply through some third
person known to both parties Should any family be pos
sessed ofony part of the Bibles only mutated copy
if they apply above, complete copy will be given.
If family be destitute and the head thereof unwl'
ling apply for Bible, any member of the family ON ap
plicaon shall have Further, if any benevolent per
knows of family in his neghbourhood, destitute of
the word of God and wishes put the Divine oraces I'm
der that roof he may apply and his request shall be
granted. Still further if there be any pious man, Of any
Christian denomination, who willing go through any Of
the Hundreds and enquire in every family whether they
are supplied with the Bible not the Delaware Bible So
cety win be glad to furnish him with Bibles for distribu.
ton, and will pay any necessary expences he may incur
in this good work.


The general Depository Of Bibles and Testaments is at
the Book store of r. Porter Son, No o. Market street.
Wilmington where the nsters of the Gospel i'd other,
willing operat. til this society requested to ap.
ply. Smaller Deposories will be made in amy part of the
County where it snail be deemed expedient


n b If Ministers would give notice OF these things to
their congregational might bring the wants OF the
people to light, and be the of good. More than
1000 Bibles and Tesamens have already been distributed
within this County, and its immediate vicinity, and yet
there are probably hundreds Of families unsupplied.
Il E. W. GILBERT,
Secretary of the Dea7vare Bible Society.

countenance, and support to their public servants,
when, in the faithful discharge of their high and re-
sponsible duties, they are assailed and abused by
ambitious asprants, who are mainly seeking to ex-
pei the present incumbents from Office, that they may
fill their places.'

Adams through Mr.. Bailey to MIR. Nv ebster for
the truth of which it vouched two members of Con-
aress, whose names $50 says the Palladium,l were


eft at that ohice.-On the 9th Of Oct. the N. York
Evening Post copied the foul tale and reinforced it
by saving s the facts'' it disclosed " had long been
in possession of the Editor of the POI thus
approprating to itself the honour and responsible
ty of the preof Positive, direct, and unqual-
lied contradictions we're Immediately given to the
story. and defiance to its inventors and pro-
pagators to produce shadow of proof in its sup
port,-and how have these been met ?--The Palla-
dum admits by its silence concerning them, either
that it knowingly published falsehoodin saying that
the names of two members of Congress were left
as authority for the story that the members of
Congress palmed the falsehood on the Editor, and
sneaking themselves from the infamy of detection,
have induced their plant tool to shoulder it-Not
one word is said of Members of Congress but a
responsible name-one name-s still pretended to
be relied upon; but, who will believe sef-convcted
witness P-and mean time the lie is permitted to
circulate as though it were established truth Nay,
it is re affirmed by the Evening Post-on what it
deemed good authority-but it names none, and
having shufled out of its own first assertion that
" the facts had been long in its possession," its
credbility too, on the point at issue, is impaired
for truth knows evasion, resorts to bubbles.
Can then any man who respects honour decency,
and fair dealing, look, with any other sentiments
than those of dstrust and Indignation, upon so vile
an attempt-so dsgracefully persevered in, to stab
the reputation of high and unimpeachable public
servants The only shadow of proof attempted to
be given in confederation of the story is little
tattle report by Mr. G.. G.. Verplanck, M. G. of
Mr.. M'Ilane's having, before going into the Presi-
dental ballot, been requested by Mr. Webster to
read letter which might affect his ultimate vote,
and which Mr. MLane refused to see.' Prodigous
Mr.. M'Lane refused to look at letter (supposing
the title to be accurately reported by the Jackal
purveyor to the Jackson lion therefore. MIR. Bailey
wrote it, and Mr.. Adams interlined it, and Mr.. Web
ster received it, and it was fraught with "atrocous
and damnabe facts and circumstances" as the Post
has it. Does not common sense and common hon.
esty revolt at such wicked absurdities ? But as
Mr.. G. C. Verplanck, NJ c. has in his private con.
yersation," and authorised publication, referred te
the name of Mr. McLane of Delaware, we may
state in respect to the opinions of that gentleman
and upon the authority of an individual whose name
left with US, is pledge for the accuracy OF what he
communicates, that as late as March Of last year.
Mr.. McLane, in conversation at Washington with
our informant said, that he believed the story o
Mr.. Adams csming into office in virtue Of any bar
gain, to be without foundation" So that whatever bt
the in ferences of Mr.. Verplanck, from the lette
that Mr.. McLane did not see, those of Mr.. M'Lan'
himself were at period more than year subsequen
to the occurrence, favourable to the purity of Mr.
Adams.


From Dover we learn that Solomon Greenly ha
been tried and found guilty of setting on fire the Do
yer Jail, and sentenced to be executed on the 20t
of November

and those who came prepared to address the assem-
blage were compelled to reinquish that purpose.
Richmond from her foundation, has seen no meeting
so powerful in numbers, so venerable from the age,
responsibility and talent of those assembled. We
knew it would be large, but it very far exceeded our
most sanguine expectations-we knew it would be
respectable, but that term is deficient in significance
to express its character.

an opposition meeting in one of the wards in n.

Boston Palladium.


From the Boston Courier.


VERMONT At the late election in this State
His Excellency Ezra Butler was reelected Cover
nor. Mr.. Swan who has been treasurer of the State
for several years was reelected, having all but eigh
teen of the votes ih the State in his favour. The
following is an extract from the inaugural Speech Of
Governor Butler.


The people of this state can never remain indf-
erent observers Of the proceedings OF Congress, or
the course pursued by the Executive of the general
government. And we have too much confidence
in the rectitude of motives, and correctness OF
our views, to conceal them. So far as the pub
lie good may require, they should be made known.
Let every state in the union do the and it may
be OF some service to that government on which we
all depend for national security, and the protection
of our rights. The dereliction of duty in the last
Congress, so we'll calculated to impair the confidence
of the public in the national legislature, is matter
of serious regret, For that body to refuse protec.
ton to the industry of majority of the people, when
the necessity had become too obvious to be mistaken
is just cause of complaint; for it is wounding te
the laudabe pride Of our country.


| Had no other important interest been neglected
the wound would have been less painful, and might
have been born in silence. However, for the pre-
sent, we can but cherish the hope. that by the mex
Congress all just cause of dissatisfaction will be re
moved, and the confidence of the people again re
stored to Legislature on whose wisdom and integ
rty, the United States, are in so high degree, de
pendent for her prosperity.


I The American system must, and will be sup
ported; Or the retrograde march Of country viii
i soon commence.


GoLatest from Europe--Papers, by the Sila
Richards, to the s4th September, have been re
ceived at New York. The chief matter of interes
is the apparent purpose of the Turks to resist tn
mediation of the European powers. The oficia
note of the Ministers of France, England and Russi
will be published in our next. Having receives
no answer, they are said to have demanded thei
passports.


Bank Robbery.-From the following advertisement
in Petersburg paper, 1t appears that the Teller
one of the Banks has absconded with large sum
money. We have not been able to gather any fu
ther particulars Mr.. Snelson is represented a
having borne fair character. His conduct is sal
to have been discreet and his habits regular an
that his style of living bordered upon parsimony
ther than extravaganza. The public are at loss
conjectures.what circumstances could have induced
man thus Situated, and grey with years, to blast hi
reputation, by such an act. 1t is said, with whs
truth we know not, that he sent $4,000 to his wife
which she returned to the Bank with promptitud
that reflects the highest credit upon her sense of hor
orr Richmond Enquirer.
:. Fsue hundred dollars re,oard-Nathaniel Snelsor
the Teller of the Office of Discount and Deposite
the Bank of Virginia, in Petersburg, has stole
from the said office about forty thousand dollars, chic
ly in notes of one hundred dollars each, the prope
ty of the President, Directors and Company, Of tn
Bank of Virginia; and he absconded early on Sur
day morning. having as is believed, very large po
tion of that with him. 1t is understood that h
got into one of the Steamboats, below City Point
the same morning.


{ am authorized by the Board of Directors Of tt
said office, to offer the above reward and all reasons
BILE expenses, for his apprehension and safe deliver
to the Jailor of this town.


Sneson is about fifty years of age, about feet
inches highs his hair very grey; his face red an
full, with clear blue eyes. He hesitates, and gene
ally appears embarrassed when speaking.
u G. w. STAINBACK, Cashier.

pei te present inCuWDeHlS LFOl OInCe, lnat lley may
fill their places"


Twenty-four passengers in the Union Steamboat
Line from Philadelphia to Baltimore, have publish
ed in the National Intelligencer, Oct 49, the /" fol-
lowing facts"


"Owing, entirely, to the careessness and intem-
perance Of two drivers, and the attempting to
pass and the other to prevent it, one of the Stages
going from Newcastle to Frenchtown. this day,
Oct 27, containing seven passengers, was over
turned, and five persons badly injured, two of them
dangerously so, viz: Rev. Bishop Kemp, of Balti-
more, and Doctor Hamilton, of Petersburgh.'


We understand that Bishop Kemp has since died
in Baltimore.


On Thursday last, the Rev. DR. u. ONDERpoNK
was consecrated Assistant Bishop of the Diocess Of
Pennsylvania. The ceremonies of Conservation took
place in Christ Church Philadelphi Sermon by
Bishop HOBART, Of New-York. j


An Administration Meeting was held at the Court
House, in Lexington, Kentucky. on the 18th inst.
for the purpose of appointing Delegates to the Con-
vention, to be held on the 18th December, to nom-
natean Electoral Ticket. The Kentucky Reporter
states that several of the most respectable Of the
Jackson party'' attended that meeting. Mr. Buc-
hanan's letter must have had its natural effect in
Kentucky, well as in other states, and the reac-
ton which has taken place on the minds of candid
and inquring men, not only has been extensive, but
will prove much more so as we hear from the most
distant parts of our country.

From the National h,teHgencer.


Extracts Of letter from Richmond dated 25th Oc-


tober.


"You will learn, with pleasure, that we held an
anti Jackson meeting in this city last evening, Judge
CABELL acting as chairman, and WM G. PENpIE-
TON, Secretary. 1t was truly the most numerous
and respectable meeting every held here, on any oc
casion whatever. The Rev. JOHN KERR, formerly
member of Congress, CHAPMAN JOHNSON, and
MIR. CALL, were appointed delegates to the Conven-
ton in January. The old Republicans Of the city
turned out in body =; and on the Corresponding
Committee you will find, among others, the names
OF Judge CARR. Mr.. STANARD, Mr. IhOs. RUTHER-
FooRD. Judge CABELI, Mr. RooTEs, Gen. HARvIE,
&c. CHAPMAN JOHNSON rode seventy miles yester-
day to reach the meeting in time and he has become
jealous and active in his exertions. You may rely
upon it that the Convention ball is moving rapidly
and it is impossible now to arrest its progress The
People are beginning TO the danger of hazarding
their liberties in the hands of General Jackson and,
with proper understanding of the relative merits
of the candidates, but little doubt is entertained.
by many cool and sagacious men, that the vote OF
| Virginia will be against the 6 Hero.' The party
here are seriously alarmed at the general movement
of the People and hence, the bold assertions OF the
Enquirer; that the objects of the convention will
fail, and their untirng efforts to defeat the measure.
The only advantage they have over us, is legsla-
tive caucus if indeed they can get up one' which
begin to doubt.''


" / forgot to tell you that our meeting consisted
of at least 600 persons The Delegates Hall was
crowded to overaowing, and many returned who
could not get in.' Sail the Judges of the court of
Appeals attended, except Judge GREEN. Conver-
sions have been made to our side in various and
different parts of the State l do not mean to
deceive you when say, that very considerable
change, in favor of the Administration, is every day
taking place."


The Heroites are shooting off their long guns and
ringing their bells for what they are pleased to call
'sa victory in Ohio" A Jackson man has been elec-
ted to Congress in the District of Ohio lately repre-
sented by Mr.. Wilson deceased, who was friendly
to the Administrations but it is well known that there
were two, if not three administration candidates to
one Heroite, and that the Heroite succeeded in
sequence of the division. There are fourteen men,
bers of the lower House of Congress and two Sen
ators from Ohio, THIRTEEN Of whom are decided
friends of the Administration. Two thirds of the
Legislature, just elected, also friendly to the Ad
ministration and in almost every instance the Jack
sonmen who did succeed were elected by diminished
maiorities. Combination may expect just such
another in victory Ohio in 1928, as they have re-
cent? gained in Delaware.


i While the charge against Mr.. Adams and Mr..
Clay continues matter Of dispute in the papers

flNUlNlhs


The meetings in Virginia, friendly to the Admi-
nistraton, multiply rapidly. On the 10th one took
place, composed of people from Shepherds Town
and its vicinity. From the preamble to their reso-
lutions, we copy the following;


1t has been admitted by all parties in this state,
that Mr.. Adams, at the last presidential election,
was the second choice Of the people of Virginia.
lti also believed that he the second choice OF
majority of our Representatives in Congress and
we have perceived nothing in his election by Con-
gress, or in his Administration since his election to
impair the confidence then reposed in him by ma
iority of the people of Virginia, although his cleo
ton and administration, have been assailed with
bitterness and violence, rarely equalled, by
one of the most formidable combinations, originating
at the seat Of government, that has ever existed in
this country; combination composed mostly of dis
appointed asprants for Office, the cement Of whose
union is no political principle.


$ The charge ofintrigue, bargain and corruption,
IN the election of Mr.. Adams, which has been cir.
cuated secretly and publicly with indefatgable in
dustry-North and South, East and West. from the
tapitol-and has been bolstered up by bold infer
ehces, dark inuendoes and the voluntary exparte
statements of unsworn and interested witnesses, can
have no credcnce with the calm, rejecting, and un-
preludced people of Virginia


The charge against Mr.. CLAY, of having made
corrupt proposition to general Jackson, has been
'r'umphanty refuted by the witnesses who were ad-
tuced to convict him, but his enemies have not yet
the masnanmiy to acknowledge it, The support
so General jackson, conscious of his inleriorty
to Mr.. Adams in all the necessary qualifications for
me o!hre of President of the United States, have
been driven into the measure of impeachng the ho-
nesty OF MIR. Adams, i'll order to degrade him below
the level of their chief, whose honesty they throw
over him as panoply which is to cover all his er-
Ir'rs and deficiencies. But has it come to this9
Is General Jackson the only honest in the Uni
ted States we have seen Mr.. Adams, in the midst
OF all the storms and connections which have been
excited around him, pursuing the policy of his pre-
decessors, with camncss, firmness, berality, and
eonstancy OF assiluity. that must command the ap
probation of all the rejecting and unprejudiced peo
Re OF the United States and we conceive it to be
inc duty of the people actively to lend their aid

We perceive, by notice in the fredericksburg
Arena, that meeting of the inhabitants of that town.
and OF Falmouth, and the adjacent country, will take
place IN Fredericksburg on the 10th of November.
LOT the purpose OF considering the expediency OF
creating company for the manufacture of woollen
and cotton cloths and linens.'' The falls of the
Rappahannock said to present great induce
ments to the erection of manufactures j; and it is
certainly very desirable to turn slave labor to
ry possible advantage.


Brazil and Buenos .Ayres-By the United States
ship Peacock, which touched at Rio Janeiro, on her
passage home from the Pacific, information was re-
ceived that new treaty was about to be offered to
the Buenos Ayreans by the Emperorof Brazil which
it was expected would be accepted, the Emperor
having abandoned the claim to the Banda Oriental,
which one of the principal features of the treaty.
Free Port in the Pacifc-By the following letter,
addressed to the Collector Of New York, it will be
seen that Free Port has been established in the
Pacific, by the Congress of Colombia.


CONSULATE OF THE UNITED STATES,


Carthagena, Oct. 1, 1927


SIR: / have the honour to hand an act OF the Con-
grass Of Colombia, declaring Buenaventura, in the
Pacific, free port, which request you will make
public. for the information of the merchants of the





obedient servant,


j. M. MACPHERSON, CoYsul.
To the Collector of the Port Of New York.


Cuba.-An official detailed report of the trade Of
the Island of Cuba for the year 1885, states that the
receipts of the Royal Treasury, in that year. are
seven millions of hard dollars This vast increase
of the public revenue says the Report, is due to the
vigilance and ability exercised in that department
tho adj ipia has enabled
government Of Cuba to meet the new and heavy ex-
penditures required in order to put the island in
spectacle state Of defence, to repair all damages to
cover all demands and there remains clear sur
plus of more than half million, at the beginning
of the present year.


| THE BIBLE OFFERED TO NIL.


Whereas it is to be feared that many families in the
County of Newcastle living without the Bible in their
houses because they deem themselves too poor to pur-
chase one, from other This is to give no.
tce all such families, that they may obtain good COM
mon Bible Testament by applying to any Minister fhe
Gospel of any Christian denomination, or to any Elder OF
Church, any Editor of Newspaper in this County.


The object of the Delaware Bible Society, and of the
other Bible Societies in this County, is to put the Bible
into every house and within the reach of every individual
To those who unable unwilling to pay any thing 1t
will be given gratuousy. From those who wiling to
pay the whole part OF the price, payment will be gladly
received and appropriated to the purchase Of others TO


When the applicant for Bible is unknown to the Min.
ster Elder or Editor he may apply through some third
person known to both parties Should any family be pos
sessed ofony part of the Bibles only mutated copy
if they apply above, complete copy will be given.
If family be destitute and the head thereof unwl'
ling apply for Bible, any member of the family ON ap
plicaon shall have Further, if any benevolent per
knows of family in his neghbourhood, destitute of
the word of God and wishes put the Divine oraces I'm
der that roof he may apply and his request shall be
granted. Still further if there be any pious man, Of any
Christian denomination, who willing go through any Of
the Hundreds and enquire in every family whether they
are supplied with the Bible not the Delaware Bible So
cety win be glad to furnish him with Bibles for distribu.
ton, and will pay any necessary expences he may incur
in this good work.


The general Depository Of Bibles and Testaments is at
the Book store of r. Porter Son, No o. Market street.
Wilmington where the nsters of the Gospel i'd other,
willing operat. til this society requested to ap.
ply. Smaller Deposories will be made in amy part of the
County where it snail be deemed expedient


n b If Ministers would give notice OF these things to
their congregational might bring the wants OF the
people to light, and be the of good. More than
1000 Bibles and Tesamens have already been distributed
within this County, and its immediate vicinity, and yet
there are probably hundreds Of families unsupplied.
Il E. W. GILBERT,
Secretary of the Dea7vare Bible Society.
: Octl30' 1897


"A y - ~ "A TIM 0EsK1KgD Ell

countenance, and support to their public servants,
when, in the faithful discharge of their high and re-
sponsible duties, they are assailed and abused by
ambitious asprants, who are mainly seeking to ex-
pei the present incumbents from Office, that they may
fill their places.'

Adams through Mr.. Bailey to MIR. Nv ebster for
the truth of which it vouched two members of Con-
aress, whose names $50 says the Palladium,l were


eft at that ohice.-On the 9th Of Oct. the N. York
Evening Post copied the foul tale and reinforced it
by saving s the facts'' it disclosed " had long been
in possession of the Editor of the POI thus
approprating to itself the honour and responsible
ty of the preof Positive, direct, and unqual-
lied contradictions we're Immediately given to the
story. and defiance to its inventors and pro-
pagators to produce shadow of proof in its sup
port,-and how have these been met ?--The Palla-
dum admits by its silence concerning them, either
that it knowingly published falsehoodin saying that
the names of two members of Congress were left
as authority for the story that the members of
Congress palmed the falsehood on the Editor, and
sneaking themselves from the infamy of detection,
have induced their plant tool to shoulder it-Not
one word is said of Members of Congress but a
responsible name-one name-s still pretended to
be relied upon; but, who will believe sef-convcted
witness P-and mean time the lie is permitted to
circulate as though it were established truth Nay,
it is re affirmed by the Evening Post-on what it
deemed good authority-but it names none, and
having shufled out of its own first assertion that
" the facts had been long in its possession," its
credbility too, on the point at issue, is impaired
for truth knows evasion, resorts to bubbles.
Can then any man who respects honour decency,
and fair dealing, look, with any other sentiments
than those of dstrust and Indignation, upon so vile
an attempt-so dsgracefully persevered in, to stab
the reputation of high and unimpeachable public
servants The only shadow of proof attempted to
be given in confederation of the story is little
tattle report by Mr. G.. G.. Verplanck, M. G. of
Mr.. M'Ilane's having, before going into the Presi-
dental ballot, been requested by Mr. Webster to
read letter which might affect his ultimate vote,
and which Mr. MLane refused to see.' Prodigous
Mr.. M'Lane refused to look at letter (supposing
the title to be accurately reported by the Jackal
purveyor to the Jackson lion therefore. MIR. Bailey
wrote it, and Mr.. Adams interlined it, and Mr.. Web
ster received it, and it was fraught with "atrocous
and damnabe facts and circumstances" as the Post
has it. Does not common sense and common hon.
esty revolt at such wicked absurdities ? But as
Mr.. G. C. Verplanck, NJ c. has in his private con.
yersation," and authorised publication, referred te
the name of Mr. McLane of Delaware, we may
state in respect to the opinions of that gentleman
and upon the authority of an individual whose name
left with US, is pledge for the accuracy OF what he
communicates, that as late as March Of last year.
Mr.. McLane, in conversation at Washington with
our informant said, that he believed the story o
Mr.. Adams csming into office in virtue Of any bar
gain, to be without foundation" So that whatever bt
the in ferences of Mr.. Verplanck, from the lette
that Mr.. McLane did not see, those of Mr.. M'Lan'
himself were at period more than year subsequen
to the occurrence, favourable to the purity of Mr.
Adams.


From Dover we learn that Solomon Greenly ha
been tried and found guilty of setting on fire the Do
yer Jail, and sentenced to be executed on the 20t
of November
